pred: Three regularization terms are introduced in the proposed approach, including neutral features, maximum entropy, and KL divergence. These terms aim to reduce the sensitivity of the prior knowledge and make the model more robust and practical. The neutral features are obtained by setting the uniform distribution, and the maximum entropy and KL divergence terms are added to the objective function to control the unbalance in the labeled features and the class distribution, respectively.

pred: Yes, the proposed pipeline components were based on deep learning models. Specifically, the Portuguese pipeline included modules for natural language processing (NLP), including part-of-speech tagging, named entity recognition, dependency parsing, semantic role labeling, subject-verb-object triple extraction, and lexicomodification. The NLP modules were implemented using the Deep Learning Library (DL-Lib) and the Portuguese dependency parsing library, which utilizes a hidden Markov model. The SRL module was also created using the Portuguese dependency parsing library, which required a different set of tags compared to the Portuguese dependency parsing library. The SVO extraction algorithm was also based

3. Another model called BIBREF10, which proposes a neural model for CWS that incorporates both word and character features

pred: Vanilla ST baseline, Pre-training Baselines, Encoder-Decoder Baseline, Pre-training Baseline, Pre-training Baseline, Pre-training Baseline, Pre-training Baseline, Pre-training Baseline, Pre-training Baseline, Pre-training Baseline, Pre-training Baseline, Pre-training Baseline, Pre-training Baseline, Pre-training Baseline, Pre-training Baseline, Pre-training Baseline, Pre-training Baseline, Pre-training Baseline, Pre-training Baseline, Pre-training Baseline, Pre-training Baseline, Pre-training Baseline, Pre-training Baseline, Pre-training Baseline, Pre-training Baseline, Pre-training
answers: Vanilla ST baseline, encoder pre-training, in which the ST encoder is initialized from an ASR model, decoder pre-training, in which the ST decoder is initialized from an MT model, encoder-decoder pre-training, where both the encoder and decoder are pre-trained, many-to-many multi-task model where the encoders and decoders are derived from pre-trained ASR and MT models, Triangle+pre-train: BIBREF18 DBLP:conf/naacl/AnastasopoulosC18 proposed a triangle multi-task strategy for speech translation
Vanilla ST baseline, Pre-training baselines, Multi-task baselines, Many-to-many+pre-training, Triangle+pre-train

Vanilla ST baseline: The vanilla ST BIBREF9 has only a speech encoder and a decoder. It is trained from scratch on the ST-TED corpus.

Pre-training baselines: We conduct three pre-training baseline experiments: 1) encoder pre-training, in which the ST encoder is initialized from an ASR model; 2) decoder pre-training, in which the ST decoder is initialized from an MT model; and 3) encoder-decoder pre-training, where both the encoder and decoder are pre-trained. The ASR model has the same architecture with vanilla ST model, trained on the mixture of ST-TED and TED-LIUM2 corpus. The MT model has a text encoder and decoder with the same architecture of which in TCEN. It is first trained on WMT data (out-of-domain) and then fine-tuned on in-domain data.

Multi-task baselines: We also conduct three multi-task baseline experiments including one-to-many setting, many-to-one setting, and many-to-many setting. In the first two settings, we train the model with $\alpha _{st}=0.75$ while $\alpha _{asr}=0.25$ or $\alpha _{mt}=0.25$. For many-to-many setting, we use $\alpha _{st}=0.6, \alpha _{asr}=0.2$ and $\alpha _{mt}=0.2$.. For MT task, we use only in-domain data.

Many-to-many+pre-training: We train a many-to-many multi-task model where the encoders and decoders are derived from pre-trained ASR and MT models.

They also compared their models to existing ones, discussing and exploring the differences in the choice of sets of Facebook pages and the features used. pred:
Word subspace

Word subspace

The word subspace is a mathematical concept that represents a set of words in a text as a low-dimensional subspace in a vector space. Word vectors, which are learned from a bag-of-words model, are used to create a word subspace, where similar words are close together and distant words are far apart. The word subspace is mathematically defined as a low-dimensional linear subspace in a word vector space, but it is limited by sparsity, as it is often high-dimensional and sparse. The word subspace can be used to capture the context of a text, which is
answers: Word vectors, usually in the context of others within the same class

pred: Yes, the paper proposes an adversarial training framework called Adversarial Reward Augmented Maximum Likelihood (ARAML) to solve the instability issue of training GANs for text generation. The paper shows that the generator is trained with an objective function that combines the reward signal from the discriminator with the reward augmented MLE training objective, which enables the generator to acquire samples from a stationary distribution around the real data, thereby reducing the instability of exploring the search space with the MLE training objective. The paper demonstrates that the generator is able to acquire samples from a fixed distribution around the real data, which helps to limit the instability of the generator
answers: ARAM has achieved improvement over all baseline methods using reverese perplexity and  slef-BLEU metric.  The maximum reverse perplexity improvement 936,16 is gained for EMNLP2017  WMT  dataset and  48,44 for COCO dataset.

Compared to the baselines, ARAML does not do better in terms of perplexity on COCO and EMNLP 2017 WMT datasets, but it does by up to 0.27 Self-BLEU points on COCO and 0.35 Self-BLEU on EMNLP 2017 WMT. In terms of Grammaticality and Relevance, it scores better than the baselines on up to 75.5% and 73% of the cases respectively.

pred: The dynamic weight adjusting strategy is employed to assign different weights to different training examples according to their respective probabilities.
answers: One can think $(1-p_{i1})$ as a weight associated with each example, which changes as training proceeds. The intuition of changing $p_{i1}$ to $(1-p_{i1}) p_{i1}$ is to push down the weight of easy examples. For easy examples whose probability are approaching 0 or 1, $(1-p_{i1}) p_{i1}$ makes the model attach significantly less focus to them. Figure FIGREF23 gives gives an explanation from the perspective in derivative: the derivative of $\frac{(1-p)p}{1+(1-p)p}$ with respect to $p$ approaches 0 immediately after $p$ approaches 0, which means the model attends less to examples once they are correctly classified.
associates each training example with a weight in proportion to $(1-p)$, and this weight dynamically changes as training proceeds

pred:
Baseline: Logistic Regression Classifier with Default Parameters

Explanation: The baseline for the FLC task is a simple logistic regression classifier with default parameters, which is a word-level classification task. This approach is a straightforward and widely used method for predicting the presence of propaganda in text. However, it is important to note that the FLC task is a composition of two subtasks: the identification of the propagandist text fragments and the identification of the techniques used. To tackle these tasks, the baseline system should generate a single feature vector for each sentence, which can be classified as propaganda or not. In the case of the FLC task, the
answers: The baseline system for the SLC task is a very simple logistic regression classifier with default parameters. The baseline for the FLC task generates spans and selects one of the 18 techniques randomly.
SLC task is a very simple logistic regression classifier, FLC task generates spans and selects one of the 18 techniques randomly

pred: Yes. The use of a multi-layer approach to assign a political bias label to different sources is crucial for the classification of news articles, as it enables the detection of different sources, including those which produce fake news, which is often accompanied by a higher level of deception.
answers: By assigning a political bias label to each news article and training only on left-biased or right-biased outlets of both disinformation and mainstream domains

we also account for political biases inherent to different news sources, referring to the procedure proposed in BIBREF2 to label different outlets. Overall we show that we are able to classify credible vs non-credible diffusion networks (and consequently news articles) with high accuracy (AUROC up to 94%), even when accounting for the political bias of sources (and training only on left-biased or right-biased articles). We observe that the layer of mentions alone conveys useful information for the classification, denoting a different usage of this functionality when sharing news belonging to the two news domains. We also show that most discriminative features, which are relative to the breadth and depth of largest cascades in different layers, are the same across the two countries.

pred: Gaussian-masked directional multi-head attention is a component of the proposed model which predicts the word boundaries of words. The model uses a bi-affine scorer which has been used in dependency parsing and semantic reasoning tasks, and it combines the information of two adjacent characters to make the relationship between two characters stronger. The Gaussian-weight matrix is used to balance the local and directional information, and the bi-affine attention layer focuses on generating the representation of input sentences by combining the information of two adjacent characters. The model predicts the word boundaries of words by calculating the probability of each segmentation gap and predicting the word boundaries of words.
answers: pays attentions to adjacent characters and casts a localness relationship between the characters as a fixed Gaussian weight assuming the weight relies on the distance between characters

Gaussian-masked directional attention can be described as a function to map queries and key-value pairs to the representation of input, Gaussian-masked directional attention expects to pay attention to the adjacent characters of each positions and cast the localness relationship between characters as a fix Gaussian weight for attention, Gaussian weight only relys on the distance between characters
